Appearance
From Wiktionary, the free dictionary
See also: halle, hallé, hälle, hallë, and Hälle

English

[edit]
English Wikipedia has an article on:
Halle (Saale)
Wikipedia

Etymology

[edit]
  • As a German surname, variant of Hall.
  • As a French surname, from the noun halle (“covered room”).
  • As a Belgian and Dutch surname, from Halle, Belgium.
  • As a Jewish surname, from Halle in Saxony, named after the river Saale.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • (female given name) enPR: hălē, IPA(key): /ˈhæli/

Proper noun

[edit]

Halle

  1. An independent city in Saxony-Anhalt, Germany.
    • 2008 June 14, The Associated Press, “Federer Extends Streak”, in The New York Times‎[1]:
      Roger Federer extended his grasscourt streak to 57 matches with a victory over Marcos Baghdatis and will play Nicolas Kiefer in the semifinals of the Gerry Weber Open in Halle, Germany.
  2. A female given name, alternative spelling of Hallie. popularized by american actress Halle Berry

Anagrams

[edit]
  • Hella, hella, hella-

Dutch

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]
  • (Gelderland) First attested as hall in 1263. Potentially a compound of Proto-Germanic *halha- (“highland spur”) and lo (“light forest on sandy soil”). Another possibility is a derivation from Middle Dutch halle (“covered market”), from Old Dutch *halla, from Frankish *hallu.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ˈɦɑ.lə/
  • Hyphenation: Hal‧le
  • Rhymes: -ɑlə

Proper noun

[edit]

Halle n

  1. a city in Flemish Brabant, Belgium
    Meronyms: Buizingen, Lembeek
  2. a village in Bronckhorst, Gelderland, Netherlands
  3. a city in Saxony-Anhalt, Germany

Derived terms

[edit]
  • Halle-Heide
  • Halle-Nijman
  • Hallenaar
  • Halls
  • Hals
  • Parelgrijs van Halle

References

[edit]
  • van Berkel, Gerard; Samplonius, Kees (2018), Nederlandse plaatsnamen verklaard (in Dutch), Mijnbestseller.nl, →ISBN

German

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ˈhalə/
  • Audio (Germany (Berlin)):(file)
  • Rhymes: -alə

Etymology 1

[edit]

From Middle High German halle, from Old High German halla, from Proto-West Germanic *hallu. Compare Low German Hall, Dutch hal, English hall, Danish hall, Swedish hall.

Noun

[edit]

Halle f (genitive Halle, plural Hallen)

  1. hall (a spacious room, especially one with a specific function)
Declension
[edit]
Declension of Halle [feminine]
singular plural
indef. def. noun def. noun
nominative eine die Halle die Hallen
genitive einer der Halle der Hallen
dative einer der Halle den Hallen
accusative eine die Halle die Hallen
Hyponyms
[edit]
  • Eingangshalle
  • Feuerhalle
  • Kaufhalle
  • Leichenhalle
  • Ruhmeshalle
  • Schwimmhalle
  • Spielhalle
  • Sporthalle
  • Turnhalle
  • Vorhalle
Derived terms
[edit]
  • Hallenbad
  • Hallenschwimmbad

Etymology 2

[edit]

Attested in early manuscripts as Halla. Of unclear origin, traditionally linked to the river Saale, whose name ultimately derives from Proto-Indo-European *séh₂ls (“salt”). Alternatively, from Proto-West Germanic *hallu (“building supported by columns”).

Proper noun

[edit]

Halle n (proper noun, genitive Halles or (optionally with an article) Halle)

  2. Halle (an independent city in Saxony-Anhalt, Germany)
    Synonyms: Halle (Saale), Halle an der Saale, Halle a/S., Halle a. d. S., Halle a. S.
  3. a town in Gütersloh district, North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany
    Synonyms: Halle (Westf.), Halle (Westfalen)
  4. a village in Grafschaft Bentheim district, Lower Saxony, Germany
  5. a municipality of the district of Holzminden, Lower Saxony, Germany
  6. a small river in North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany
  7. a city and municipality of the district of Halle-Vilvoorde, province of Flemish Brabant, Belgium
Derived terms
[edit]
  • hallisch
  • Hallenser
  • Haller

References

[edit]
  • Steffen Drenkelfuss: Halle – die schräge Stadt. In: Mitteldeutsche Zeitung (Halle/Saalkreis)
